title: The early history of Spain's Gypsies from 1425 to 1783
abstractText: While much has been written about Spain's minority Jewish, Muslim and converted morisco population in the late medieval and early modern periods, comparatively little scholarly attention has been devoted to its Gypsies. Pioneering studies produces by Spanish, French, and American scholars have tended on the whole to be relatively narrow in focus or to concentrate for the most part in the last three centuries. The Gypsies of Early Modern Spain, 1425-1783 (Basingstoke: Palgrave-Macmillan, 2007) is the first historical study in English of Spain's gypsies of the late medieval and early modern periods. Drawing extensively on the author's archival research in Spain, it reconstruct the first three and a half centuries there are people who, despite their elevation by non-Spaniards to culturally iconic status in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries, have until now remained largely invisible to history in the English-speaking world.
